Body:
This could be an influence of the other my not-quite-native languages, but let's think about this: is Russian 'irregular' stress pattern really such a mess as we often think of it?

E.g. the negation particle не when added to a verb could be pronounced differently. When a stress falls on the first syllable, it sounds as [ni]: не помню; не слышу; не знаю; не спрашивай.

When the stress falls on a syllable other than the first one, it is pronounced as [ne]: не хочу; не желаю; не могу.

Both [ni] and [ne] are unstressed, yet pronounced differently (well, in the articulation I hear, at least).

Questions:

  1. Is there any other evidence of such interdependance between stress location and pronunciation in Russian (e.g. in words with consonant/vowel change)?

  2. Could the shifting stress be related to specific grammatical forms?

  3. Is the Russian stress position unique to Eastern Slavic languages, or are there examples of 'irregular' stress patterns in other languages?
Title: Is Russian 'irregular' stress pattern really 'irregular'?
